text.p: These are the leading stories in the Belgrade press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Yugoslavia's membership in IMF still "on ice" says paper. Talks between finance minister Tomica Raicevic and the fund in Washington will be of informative nature.
- Serbian President Milosevic and Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic to meet in a third country this week, says Slovenian paper.
- "If the police resorts to violence we shall respond with violence" says secretary of the trade union of Zastava arms Dragutin Stanojlovic on twelvth day of protest in Kragujevac.
- Food producers announce new price increases thanks partly to rise in prices of power and other services, says expert at Institute for market research.
- The federal government will propose to the Central bank a five-year deferral of the repayment of credits of the agrarian sector, says Yugoslav Agriculture Minister Tihomir Vrebalov.
- Three documents on strengthening of Yugoslav-Polish ties signed during Polish Foreign Minister Dariusz Rosati's visit to Belgrade.

- Before departing for a new round of talks on the succession of the former Yugoslavia in Brussels, the Yugoslav team said the succession memorandum proposed by mediator Sir Arthur Watts does not lead to a solution.
- One of the biggest international marketing agencies TBWA to open its office in Belgrade in early 1997.
- Croatian army military inspection team to visit Yugoslavia in mid-September within the scope of the agreement on sub-regional arms control of states of the former Yugoslavia.
- Yugoslav economy marked modest but positive results, says economy committee of the Yugoslav chamber of commerce.

- It is true that diamond-bearing rocks were found in the Berane area, northern Montenegro, says director of Berane coal mine Ziviojin Djuraskovic. Experts now have to determine if there are diamonds.
